'''WAAKE-UP!''' ('''World Awareness and Action Koalition of Equal United Progressives''') was a student and community coalition at the [[University of Colorado Boulder]] (CU-Boulder) active from 1998 to 2001. WAAKE-UP! adopted the motto "Action without Awareness is ignorant. Awareness without Action is immoral." WAAKE-UP! supported many progressive causes, but were best known for the "[[Sweatshop]] Campaign," demanding that [[University of Colorado Boulder|University of Colorado]] apparel be made in factories supporting fair labor conditions, specifically those endorsed by the [[Worker Rights Consortium]]. The Sweatshop Campaign was not successful, but its goals were later fulfilled by WAAKE-UP!'s successor organizations, 180 at 11 (180 degrees at the 11th hour), CASA (Coalition Against Sweatshop Apparel) and WWJC (World Workers Justice Committee). Like many other progressive organizations in [[Colorado]] their actions were recorded in the Denver Police Spy Files.<ref name="ACLUSPY2006">{{cite web|url=http://www.aclu-co.org/spyfiles/samplefiles.htm |title=ACLU of Colorado: Spy Files |accessdate=2007-09-18 |author=ACLU of Colorado |date=2006-02-24 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070808135029/http://www.aclu-co.org/spyfiles/samplefiles.htm |archivedate=2007-08-08 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==The Sweatshop Campaign== July, 1996 the [[University of Colorado system|University of Colorado]] board of regents adopted the [[Talloires Declaration]] stating that the University must maintain "institutional neutrality in social and political matters" unless it is an issue that "directly affects the university, is detrimental to the achievement of the university's mission and purposes, and/or threatens [[academic freedom]]."<ref name="NEUTRALITY">{{cite news|author=Oakland L. Childers|title=U. Colorado student group takes on regents' neutrality policy|date=1999-04-06|publisher=University Wire|accessdate=2007-09-22|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-21197490.html}}{{Dead link|date=April 2016}}</ref>
April 1, 1999 CU-Boulder's student union legislative council unanimously passed Council Resolution 106 suggesting CU regents, Chancellor Richard Byyny, and President John Buechner adopt a Basic Commitment to Human Rights, requiring them to take a stand against environmentally irresponsible investments and apparel contracts. The following Monday, April 5, WAAKE-UP! held a press conference asking the University to abandon its institutional neutrality policy for a "institutional integrity policy." WAAKE-UP! members asked the University of Colorado to stop investing in corporations committing human rights violations even if the investments were more lucrative than [[Socially responsible investing|socially responsible alternatives]]. Specifically, WAAKE-UP! members were displeased with the University's investments in corporations like [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]], [[Royal Dutch Shell]], [[Louisiana-Pacific]], [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]], [[Lehman Brothers]] (the parent company of [[Peabody Energy|Peabody Coal]]), [[Texaco]] and [[Unocal]].<ref name="NEUTRALITY"/>
WAAKE-UP! faxed and emailed documentation violations of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] committed by corporations invested in by the [[University of Colorado system|University of Colorado]] to the regents, Byyny and Buechner, demanding they support Council Resolution 106 by April 12. None of the University officials responded.<ref name="NEUTRALITY"/>
April 26, 1999, WAAKE-UP! held a rally at the Dalton Trumbo Fountain outside the University Memorial Center on the CU-Boulder campus encouraging the [[University of Colorado Boulder|University of Colorado]], to dissolve the University's neutrality policy on investments and sign a basic commitment to [[human rights]]. Byyny refused to meet with the protesters. In response, WAAKE-UP! organized a protest on April 28, 1999, blocking traffic at the intersection of Broadway and Regent Drive (located on the edge of the Boulder campus) until Byyny agreed to speak with them. He scheduled an appointment to speak with WAAKE-UP! members on April 30, 1999, at 8 a.m.<ref name="CODAILY041999">{{cite news|author=Oakland L. Childers|title=Group brings U. Colorado-investments protest to the boulevard|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-21355301.html|newspaper=Colorado Daily|date=1999-04-28|accessdate=2010-01-03}}{{Dead link|date=April 2016}}</ref> WAAKE-UP! continued to organize and grow over the next year.<ref name="POSTSDEMANDS">{{cite news|author=Pamela White |date=2000-03-03 |title=WAAKE-UP! student group posts demands at U. Colorado |publisher=University Wire |accessdate=2007-09-21 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-25241456.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516200402/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-25241456.html |archivedate=May 16, 2011 }}</ref>
===March 2000=== March 2, 2000, and again on March 15, 2000, WAAKE-UP! presented Chancellor Richard Byyny with a series of demands to ensure ethical apparel licensing was practiced by the University of Colorado. Byyny responded that he would consider adopting them but needed time, more community input, and expressed some specific concerns. Byyny questioned whether one of WAAKE-UP!'s demands, [[equal pay for women]] making [[University of Colorado system|University of Colorado]] apparel, was a [[human right]] or a [[cultural norm]]. According to the [[United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] it is not a cultural norm, Article 23, Section 2 states: "Everyone, without any discrimination, has the right to equal pay for equal work."<ref name="POSTSDEMANDS"/><ref name="CODAILY03172000">{{cite news|author=Pamela White|title=Opinion: Byyny fails CU at WAAKE-UP! talks: Spirit of Norlin dead at CU|date=2000-03-17|accessdate=2007-09-21|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/march2k.html#3/17|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020308001325/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/march2k.html#3/17|archivedate=2002-03-08}}</ref><ref name="MEASURES">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland |title=U. Colorado chancellor, students debate anti-sweatshop measures |date=2000-03-16 |publisher=University Wire |accessdate=2007-09-22 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-25493515.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516200506/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-25493515.html |archivedate=May 16, 2011 }}</ref>
March 19, 2000, WAAKE-UP! members protested outside of the [[Abercrombie & Fitch]] store on the [[Pearl Street Mall]] in [[Boulder, Colorado]], a few blocks away from the CU-Boulder campus. WAAKE-UP! claimed Abercrombie & Fitch laborers were exploited and worked in [[sweatshop]] conditions.<ref name="CODAILY03202000">{{cite news|title=Colorado Daily Front Page|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/march2k.html#3/20|publisher=Colorado Daily|date=2000-03-20|accessdate=2007-09-18|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020308001325/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/march2k.html#3/20|archivedate=2002-03-08}}</ref>
March 21, 2000, CU-Boulder professor [[Ira Chernus]] announced that he had written a resolution in support of WAAKE-UP!'s demands and that it would be voted on during the next Boulder Faculty Assembly. It included creating a Code of Conduct for Ethical Apparel Licensing as well as an Investment Board of Ethics which would be monitored by an Internal Advisory Board for compliance with the Code of Conduct.<ref name="CODAILY03222000">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=CU profs may support Code: BFA to consider sweatshop resolution|date=2000-03-17|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]}}</ref> This was in addition to resolutions passed by the Assembly on March 13, 2000, calling for WAAKE-UP!, Byyny, and Vice Chancellor Ronald Stump to continue a good-faith discussion on University of Colorado apparel licensing.<ref name="BEER2000A">{{cite web|url=http://www.colorado.edu/FacultyGovernance/MOTRES/xr1-0300.html |title=BFAX-R-1-0300: Facilitation |accessdate=2010-01-03 |author=Francis A. Beer |author2=Sierra Swearingen |author3=Britt Cartrite |date=2000-03-13 |archivedate=2010-01-03 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mUlQw1Z9?url=http://www.colorado.edu/FacultyGovernance/MOTRES/xr1-0300.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The resolutions were forwarded to the Chancellor's office on March 14, 2000.<ref name="BEER2000B">{{cite web|url=http://www.colorado.edu/FacultyGovernance/MOTRES/index.html |title=BFA Motions and Resolutions |accessdate=2010-01-02 |author=Francis A. Beer |author2=Sierra Swearingen |author3=Britt Cartrite |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mUlXiCd3?url=http://www.colorado.edu/FacultyGovernance/MOTRES/index.html |archivedate=2010-01-03 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="BEER2000C">{{cite web|url=http://www.colorado.edu/FacultyGovernance/EXCOM/XMINARCH/XARCH00/031300.html |title=BFA Executive Committee Minutes |accessdate=2010-01-03 |author=Francis A. Beer |author2=Sierra Swearingen |author3=Britt Cartrite |date=2000-03-13 |archivedate=2000-09-19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000919212421/http://www.colorado.edu/FacultyGovernance/EXCOM/XMINARCH/XARCH00/031300.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===April 2000=== April 4, 2000, WAAKE-UP! held a mock trial outside the University Memorial Center by the Dalton Trumbo Fountain with the "Sweatshop King", a {{convert|10|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} street theater puppet. University of Colorado police officers, Detective Tim DeLaria and Lt. Michelle Irving monitored the demonstration and took photographs of those participating. Both officers belonged to the Investigations and Community Service Unit of the [[University of Colorado Boulder|University of Colorado]] Police Department.<ref name="LANGELAND2000A">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title="Sweatshop King" reigns: Cops keep eye on WAAKE-UP! rally, students demand "no sweat"|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/5%20sweatr|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|date=2000-04-05|accessdate=2007-09-18|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/5%20sweatr|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref>
April 5, 2000, WAAKE-UP! demanded that the University of Colorado join the [[Worker Rights Consortium]] by the end of the day on April 6, 2000. Meeting this deadline would have allowed representatives from the University to attend a [[Worker Rights Consortium]] meeting taking place in New York City on April 7, 2000.<ref name="LANGELAND2000B">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=Sweatshop issue gaining momentum: WAAKE-UP! gives CU deadline to join WRC|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/6|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|date=2000-04-06|accessdate=2007-09-18|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/6|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref>
April 6, 2000, the Boulder Faculty Assembly voted in favor of a resolution supporting WAAKE-UP!'s demands, though it didn't specifically include the requirement that the University of Colorado should join the [[Worker Rights Consortium]]. The resolution was passed on a voice vote with 30 faculty members in attendance, the vast majority voting in favor of it.<ref name="LANGELAND2000C">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=BFA demands "no sweat"|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/7%20daily%20bfa|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|date=2000-04-07|accessdate=2007-09-18|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/7%20daily%20bfa|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref> The Assembly claimed that the [[United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] served as a basis for the proposed Code of Conduct. Byyny created an ad hoc group of ten [[University of Colorado Boulder|CU-Boulder]] faculty, staff, and students to investigate WAAKE-UP!'s proposal. Byyny's ad hoc group's first meeting was behind closed doors, against Colorado's [[Open Meeting Law]]<ref name="LANGELAND2000C 2">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=Habitat for humanity|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/11%20shanty|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|date=2000-04-11|accessdate=2007-09-18|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/11%20shanty|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref> WAAKE-UP! was invited to attend the first meeting, but boycotted it in protest. A WAAKE-UP! member was present at all subsequent meetings.<ref name="LANGELAND2000D">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=WAAKE-UP! will attend: But students are critical of CU administration's "task group" meeting|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/11%20shanty|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|date=2000-04-11|accessdate=2007-09-18|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/11%20shanty|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref>
The Boulder Faculty Assembly had organized three community forums in an effort to get the community input Byyny requested. Byyny never attended any of the forums organized by the Assembly. University of Colorado Vice Chancellor Paul Tabolt, however, attended one of the forums and raised a few questions, but left without giving forum attendees a chance to respond to them.<ref name="LANGELAND2000C"/> Tabolt stated [[collective bargaining]] is not a right (an opinion not supported by the [[United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights]]) and that he believed it was fair to pay workers less than what they need to live.<ref>{{cite news|title=Opinion: CU showing its true colors|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/10%20opinion|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|date=2000-04-10|accessdate=2007-09-18|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/10%20opinion|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref>
April 7, 2000, the University of Colorado Student Union unanimously supported WAAKE-UP!'s demand that the University join the [[Worker Rights Consortium]], passing on a vote of 13–0. However, this failed to produce any action from the Office of the Chancellor.<ref>{{cite news|title=Student reps back WRC: Note campus support growing for anti-sweatshop measures; Byyny's task force to meet today|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/10%20ucsu|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|date=2000-04-10|accessdate=2007-09-18|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/10%20ucsu|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref>
In the meantime WAAKE-UP! was busy circulating a petition among students demanding that the University of Colorado join the Worker Rights Consortium (gathering over 2000 signatures) and on April 10, 2000, and built a [[shantytown]] in the Norlin Quadrangle on the CU-Boulder campus to draw attention to their campaign and gain visibility during the [[Conference on World Affairs]]. In reference to the conference, WAAKE-UP! members named the shantytown the "Conference on World Despairs." WAAKE-UP! initially created the shantytown without the University's permission, but later obtained "temporary structure" permits after it was established. The construction of the shantytown started just hours before the [[Conference on World Affairs]]' opening procession through the Norlin Quadrangle. WAAKE-UP! said the shantytown was meant to symbolize the poor living conditions of sweatshop workers. WAAKE-UP!'s shanytown was reminiscent of a previous one constructed in 1988 outside the Dalton Trumbo Fountain to protest the University of Colorado's investment in the South African [[apartheid]] regime.<ref name="HABITAT">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=Habitat for humanity|date=2000-04-11|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/11%20shanty|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|accessdate=2007-09-21|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/11%20shanty|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref><ref name="POPPEN2000">{{cite news|author=Julie Poppen|title=Students demand CU join consortium: Protesters want CU to be sure sweatshops don't make university-licensed apparel|publisher=[[Daily Camera]]|date=2000-04-11|accessdate=2007-09-21|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/11%20camera|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/11%20camera|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref><ref name="STILLSTANDS">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland |date=2000-04-12 |title=Anti-sweatshop still stands at U. Colorado despite threats |publisher=University Wire |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-25798656.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516200412/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-25798656.html |archivedate=May 16, 2011 }}</ref>
WAAKE-UP! members stayed at the [[shantytown]] in shifts during the day and night. During the day they held teach-ins, distributed fliers, and explained the purpose of the shantytown to passersby. Among other topics, WAAKE-UP! members discussed [[Gary Barnett]]'s threats to suspend players covering up [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] logos on their uniforms. Community members and local businesses supported them by supplying food and water.<ref name="STILLSTANDS"/><ref name="CAMP">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=Camp still stands: Threat of removal doesn't deter activists|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|date=2000-04-12|accessdate=2007-09-21|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/12%20daily|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/12%20daily|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref><ref name="SWOOSH">{{cite news|author=Ted Dawson and Terje Langeland |title=Colorado football players punished for covering up Nike 'swoosh' |date=2000-04-26 |publisher=University Wire |accessdate=2007-09-22 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-26204539.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516200516/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-26204539.html |archivedate=May 16, 2011 }}</ref> At 3 a.m. on April 13, 2000, approximately ten people came by the shantytown and set off fireworks, threw water balloons and distributed flyers that read "kegs not contraversy (sic)." WAAKE-UP! members sleeping at the [[shantytown]] said they appreciated the [[nonviolent]] protest methods used by the "anti-protest protesters."<ref name="SHANTYTOWN">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=Shantytown's future uncertain|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|accessdate=2007-09-21|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/14%20shanty|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/14%20shanty|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref> April 15, 2000 WAAKE-UP! members staying at the shantytown abandoned it due to heavy snow, but later returned. April 17, 2000 more than 150 people attended a rally at WAAKE-UP!'s shantytown focusing on high school education and in solidarity with protests the previous day in [[Washington D.C.]] against the [[International Monetary Fund]] and [[World Bank]].<ref name="SNOWFALL">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=Snowfall only temporary setback for shantytown|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|date=2000-04-17|accessdate=2007-09-21|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/17%20shanty|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/17%20shanty|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref> April 13, 2000, WAAKE-UP! began meeting with the ad hoc committee formed by Chancellor Byyny. Though both sides claimed progress was being made, the University administration favored joining the [[Fair Labor Association]] over the [[Worker Rights Consortium]]. WAAKE-UP! were critical of the Fair Labor Association as much of its funding came from organizations it monitored creating a potential [[conflict of interest]].<ref name="PROGRESS">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=Progress made on students' demands: WAAKE-UP! meets with CU on code of conduct|date=2000-04-14|accessdate=2007-09-21|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/14|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/14|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref><ref name="TASKFORCE">{{cite news|title=Task force discusses sweatshop labor|date=2000-04-14|accessdate=2007-09-21|publisher=[[Daily Camera]]|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/14%20camera|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/14%20camera|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref>
April 17, 2000, the ad hoc group put together by Byyny recommended a one-year conditional membership in the Worker Rights Consortium, though it still needed to be approved by a larger ad hoc committee, appointed by the Chancellor, and the Chancellor himself. The committee also recommended they monitor the [[Fair Labor Association]] during that year to decide if it would be worth joining. Additionally, the committee raised some questions as to how the Code of Conduct would apply to contracts [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] had with the CU-Boulder athletics department, which operated somewhat autonomously.<ref name="GROUPAPPROVES">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=Group approves WRC: CU subcommittee endorses joining consortium for one-year trial, but move still needs Byyny's approval|date=2000-04-18|accessdate=2007-09-21|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/18|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/18|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref><ref name="ADAMS2000">{{cite news|author=Emma Adams|title=No proposals from CU labor panel|date=2000-04-18|accessdate=2007-09-21|publisher=[[Daily Camera]]|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/18%20camera|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/18%20camera|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref>
By April 19, 2000 the larger ad hoc committee said it was putting the finishing touches on the Code of Conduct and were getting ready to send it to Byyny to review.<ref name="ONEAUTOGRAPH">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=One autograph away: CU's membership in sweatshop watchdog group now hinges on chancellor's signature|date=2000-04-19|accessdate=2007-09-21|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/19|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/19|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref> WAAKE-UP! pressured Byyny to sign it as soon as he possibly could.<ref name="NEXTWEEK">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=Students press Byynt on WRC: Chancellor unlikely to sign agreement until next week|date=2000-04-20|accessdate=2007-09-21|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/20|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/20|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref>
April 25, 2000, Chancellor Byyny announced that he would not sign the [[anti-sweatshop]] policy approved by the ad hoc committees. Instead, Byyny made some changes to the existing policy using the committee's recommendations as guidelines.<ref name="WHITE2000">{{cite news|author=Pamela White|title=Byyny ought to resign|date=2000-04-27|accessdate=2007-09-21|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/27%20pamela|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/27%20pamela|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref>
April 26, 2000, [[Ralph Nader]] visited the CU-Boulder campus. Nader endorsed WAAKE-UP!'s demands and condemned Byyny's decision not to join the Worker Rights Consortium. Nader speculated that the University's decision might be influenced by an announcement [[Phil Knight]] had recently made, stating that he would retract a thirty million dollar donation to the [[University of Oregon]] after they joined the [[Worker Rights Consortium]].<ref name="NADER">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=Nader backs WAAKE-UP!|date=2000-04-27|accessdate=2007-09-21|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/27%20nader|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/27%20nader|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref>
WAAKE-UP! met with Byyny the same day. Byyny gave few specifics about his decision not to follow the committee's recommendations. A WAAKE-UP! member had brought a water gun to the meeting, and showed it to the police officers present. Later in the meeting officer Tim DeLaria attempted to grab the water gun out of the activist's hand, causing it to squirt two other officers. DeLaria attempted to arrest the activist for this, though Police Lt. John Kish reversed DeLaria's decision and let the water-gun carrying activist off with a warning. Professor Ira Chernus had protested the unnecessary show of force during this and previous meetings.<ref name="HEAT">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland|title=Chancellor takes heat|date=2000-04-27|accessdate=2007-09-21|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/27%20byyny|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/27%20byyny|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref>
===May 2000=== May 3, 2000, Byyny signed a revised version of the university apparel licensing policy recommended by the executive committee. The revisions were made in a closed door meeting, and public input was not sought on the changes. The revised version required licensees to comply with labor laws and regulations of their governments, and prohibited discrimination, harassment, child labor, [[Unfree labour|forced labor]] and [[Penal labour|prison labor]].<ref name="REALCHANGE">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland |title=U. Colorado signs apparel policy, activists promise to fight for 'real change' |date=2000-03-04 |publisher=University Wire |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-26399077.html |accessdate=2007-09-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516200432/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-26399077.html |archivedate=May 16, 2011 }}</ref> WAAKE-UP! members were disappointed with vague language used in revision and weakened stance on [[women's rights]] and maximum hours allowed in a [[workweek]].<ref name="VAGUE">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland |title=Anti-sweatshop activists call proposed U. Colorado code too 'vague' |date=2000-05-03 |publisher=University Wire |accessdate=2007-09-22 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-26374850.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516200922/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-26374850.html |archivedate=May 16, 2011 }}</ref>
May 4, 2000, in response to Byyny's rejection of the committee's licensing recommendations, WAAKE-UP! and Boulder [[Biotic Baking Brigade]] member, Sara Toombs (a.k.a. Agent Moon Pie), [[Pieing|pied]] Chancellor Byyny while he was giving a speech on the CU-Boulder campus.<ref name="BBB2001">{{cite news|url=http://bioticbakingbrigade.org/communique011301.html |title=Just dessets: Sweet confection targeted CU policy on sweatshop labor |accessdate=2010-01-03 |author=Michael A. de Yoanna |date=January 2001 |publisher=[[Colorado Daily]] |archivedate=2003-04-11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030411190638/http://bioticbakingbrigade.org/communique011301.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Toombs was later tried for [[assault]]. Byyny claimed he incurred numerous [[dry cleaning]] bills and that his cheek was slightly bruised as a result of the pieing. Toombs testified at the trial that she baked the organic blueberry pie herself, and that she used her training in [[nonviolent resistance]] techniques as well as the benefit of practice with friends to "squoosh" the pie in Byyny's face without harming him. The jury found that she was not guilty of assault but did find her guilty of [[harassment]] and [[Mischief|criminal mischief]]. Toombs was sentenced to six months of unsupervised probation, thirty hours of [[community service]], and was ordered to write Byyny a letter of apology. The verdict was considered a victory by Toombs, her attorneys, and her supporters.<ref name="BBB2001"/>
Before the trial WAAKE-UP! members staged a "sui-pied", a demonstration where they hit themselves in the face with pies to show how harmless it was, outside the Boulder County Justice Center.<ref name="BBB2001"/>
===September 2000=== September 18, 2000, the University of Colorado confirmed suspicions it had joined the [[Fair Labor Association]] on May 3, 2000. WAAKE-UP! members had only learned of the decision from a discussion with a FLA representative, and were upset that they were not consulted about or informed of the decision.<ref name="HOYA2000">{{cite news|url=http://www.thehoya.com/news/092200/news9.htm |title=Students Perceive Move to DLA as 'Betrayal' |accessdate=2007-09-19 |date=2000-09-22 |publisher=[[The Hoya]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929091853/http://www.thehoya.com/news/092200/news9.htm |archivedate=2007-09-29 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="FLABETRAYAL">{{cite news|author=Terje Langeland |title=U. Colorado joins Fair Labor Association; student activists view decision as 'betrayal' |date=2000-09-20 |publisher=University Wire |accessdate=2007-09-22 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-32310150.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516200847/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-32310150.html |archivedate=May 16, 2011 }}</ref> Following the news, WAAKE-UP! members said they would continue the campaign making three demands on the University: (1) to adopt a strong licensing policy that will eliminate the possibility of doing business with companies that use sweatshop labor, (2) form an internal monitoring board within the University of Colorado that will evaluate whether companies comply with the licensing policy and to investigate and research possible violations, and (3) to join the Worker Rights Consortium (WRC) as an external monitoring agency that will investigate conditions in the factories in which apparel is made. Although it was not in the three demands, WAAKE-UP! also asked that the University relinquish its membership in the [[Fair Labor Association]].<ref name="WADLINGE">{{cite web|url=http://ucsu.colorado.edu/~wadlinge/actnow.html|author=Nina Wadlinger|title=ACTION|accessdate=2007-09-19|date=April 2001|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010428120525/http://ucsu.colorado.edu/~wadlinge/actnow.html|archivedate=2001-04-28}}</ref>
===Continued organizing and victory=== November 15, 2001 former WAAKE-UP! organizer Scott Silber returned to CU-Boulder to give a talk titled ''American Jihad Inc.: Corporate Crusades for the Free Market Faith'' about corporate influence in the post-September 11 world.<ref name="WEEKLY2001">{{cite news|url=http://www.boulderweekly.com/archive/111501/newsspin.html|author=Editorial Staff|title=Scott Silber WAAKEs up CU: Sweat shop activist returns|date=2001-11-15|publisher=[[Boulder Weekly]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051122202527/http://www.boulderweekly.com/archive/111501/newsspin.html|archivedate=2005-11-22}}</ref>
From 2004 to 2006 the student groups 180 degrees at the 11th hour, CASA (Coalition Against Sweatshop Apparel), and WWJC (World Workers Justice Committee) organized on the [[University of Colorado Boulder|CU-Boulder]] campus, again trying to get the University to join the [[Worker Rights Consortium]], this time petitioning Chancellor Phil Distefano.<ref name="WEEKLY2005">{{cite news|url=http://www.boulderweekly.com/archive/031705/coverstory.html|author=Pamela White|title=The triumphant return of crachers: A pissed-off corporate-crime-fighting chicken comes back to CU to end sweatshop abuses|date=2005-03-17|publisher=[[Boulder Weekly]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051122221510/http://www.boulderweekly.com/archive/031705/coverstory.html|archivedate=2005-11-22}}</ref>
May 5, 2005, the groups held a hunger strike inside Distefano's office, until it was announced that the University would begin the affiliation process. CASA members again went on hunger strike for fifteen days from April 12 to April 27, 2006 until the University accepted the Designated Supplier Program proposed by the United Students Against Sweatshops.<ref name="RMR">{{cite news|url=http://rockymountainresister.org/?q=node/10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009174927/http://rockymountainresister.org/?q=node%2F10|archivedate=2007-10-09|title=24-HR. Hunger Strike, Occupation Ends 6-Year CU Sweatshop Fight|date=2005-05-07|publisher=The Rocky Mountain Resister|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>
==Other causes and campaigns== === Career fair demonstration === WAAKE-UP! members had requested a table at career fairs held on the CU-Boulder campus to inform students about the behavior of corporations trying to recruit them, but had been denied by CU-Boulder administration. In response, on January 31, 2000, WAAKE-UP! held a demonstration during a career fair, accompanied by [[TV Nation]]'s Crackers the Corporate Crime-Fighting Chicken, carrying a banner that read "Students are NOT products, Teachers are NOT tools, The University is NOT a factory!"<ref name="GEORGEANNEDAILY">{{cite news|url=http://www.stp.georgiasouthern.edu/George-Anne/arc5/spr00/0131nws.html |author=TMS Campus |title=National News Brief: Students protest at U. of Colo. |date=2000-01-31 |publisher=[[The George-Anne Daily]] |accessdate=2010-01-02 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060909091236/http://www.stp.georgiasouthern.edu/George-Anne/arc5/spr00/0131nws.html |archivedate=2006-09-09 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="CAREERFAIR">{{cite news|author=Amanda Hill |title=U. Colorado group protests career fair |date=2000-01-26 |publisher=University Wire |accessdate=2007-09-22 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-24764377.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516200557/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-24764377.html |archivedate=May 16, 2011 }}</ref>
===Die-in to support the U'wa=== March 14, 2000, WAAKE-UP! members staged a [[die-in]] in front of the World Trade Center buildings in [[Denver, Colorado]] to raise awareness about the [[U'wa people|U'wa]]'s struggle against the [[Occidental Petroleum Corporation]]. There were approximate 20 police officers at the protest who dragged the limp protesters away from the scene, at one point dragging a protester's head into a [[street gutter]]. One of the protesters was taken in to custody without being read his [[Miranda Rights]].<ref name="HALFHOUR">{{cite news|author=Leo Griep-Ruiz|title=Opinion: A half hour in downtown Denver|date=2000-03-21|accessdate=2007-09-21|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/march2k.html#3/20|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020308001325/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/march2k.html#3/20|archivedate=2002-03-08}}</ref>
===A16 solidarity march=== On April 15, 2000 WAAKE-UP! organized a march of more than 400 people in Boulder in solidarity with protests of the [[World Bank]] and [[International Monetary Fund]] in [[Washington D.C.]]. The protests were a continuation of those at the [[WTO Ministerial Conference of 1999 protest activity|Ministerial Conference of 1999]] in [[Seattle, Washington]].<ref name="INDYMEDIA">{{cite web|url=http://dc.indymedia.org/newswire/display/850 |title=A15 – Boulder, CO, Solidarity March |date=2000-04-16 |author=Tammi Laninga |publisher=[[Washington, D.C.|DC]] [[Independent Media Center|Indymedia]] |archivedate=2010-01-03 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mUmIkxS8?url=http://dc.indymedia.org/newswire/display/850 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> On April 9, 2000, The ''[[Daily Camera]]'' published an article by Ira Chernus in support of the march supporting the protest. Speakers at the protest included Cecilia Zarate-Laun and David Pellow.<ref name="LOCALA15">{{cite news|author =Amanda Hill|title=Local A15 events slated|date=2000-04-11|accessdate=2007-09-27|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/11%20a15|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/11%20a15|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref> The protest was non-violent and there was no hostile contact with the police during it.<ref name="MIRRORED">{{cite news|author =Amanda Hill|title=Protest in Washington D.C. mirrored in Boulder|date=2000-04-17|accessdate=2007-09-27|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/17%20a15daily|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116070056/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/april2k.html#4/17%20a15daily|archivedate=2004-01-16}}</ref>
Some WAAKE-UP! members, however, went to the April 16 protest in Washington D.C., and came prepared to treat protesters who might be injured. They brought medical supplies and treated people who had been [[pepper spray]]ed.<ref name="PLAINSMAN2000">{{cite news|url=http://www.auburn.edu/student_info/plainsman/archives/042000/042000nprotest.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050507092543/http://www.auburn.edu/student_info/plainsman/archives/042000/042000nprotest.html|archivedate=2005-05-07|title="This is what democracy looks like." : Protests Erupt in Washington, D.C.|date=2000-04-20|author=Matt Comer|publisher=[[The Auburn Plainsman]]}}</ref>
===Flatirons Crossing protest=== August 11, 2000, WAAKE-UP! members protested the opening of the Flatirons Crossing mall in [[Broomfield, Colorado]]. WAAKE-UP! believed the mall promoted [[consumerism]] and contributed to [[urban sprawl]].<ref name="CAMPUSPRESS">{{cite news|url=http://newmedia.colorado.edu/press/stories/pages/110.html |title=FlatIron Crossing takes shopping to the extreme |date=2000-09-20 |publisher=[[The Campus Press]] |author=Hanh Tran |archivedate=2001-03-03 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010303165340/http://newmedia.colorado.edu/press/stories/pages/110.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===S26 Solidarity March=== September 25, 2000, WAAKE-UP! members and other activists marched on [[Pearl Street Mall]] in [[Boulder, Colorado]]. The action was in solidarity with protests against the [[International Monetary Fund]] and [[World Bank]] in [[Prague]]. Protesters urged passersby at stores on the Pearl Street Mall such as [[Gap (clothing retailer)|GAP]], [[Banana Republic (clothing retailer)|Banana Republic]], [[Abercrombie & Fitch]], [[Starbucks]], and [[Borders Group|Borders Bookstore]] (under construction at the time) to support local business, chanting "Take your crap back to the Gap" and "Human need, not corporate greed." This was a smaller protest compared to one following it in [[Denver, Colorado]] on September 26, 2000.<ref name="YOANNA20000925">{{cite news|url=http://www.colorado.edu/AmStudies/lewis/2010/gap.htm |title=Boulderites unite with Prague protesters: Denver demonstration slated for Tuesday |date=2000-09-25 |publisher=[[Colorado Daily]] |author=Michael A. de Yoanna |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mUr1A3YP?url=http://www.colorado.edu/AmStudies/lewis/2010/gap.htm |archivedate=2010-01-03 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="PARKER">{{cite news|title=Views mixed on local vs. outside-owned businesses|date=2000-09-25|publisher=[[Colorado Daily]]|author=Lisa Parker|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/s2k.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040119102934/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~amnesty/s2k.html|archivedate=2004-01-19}}</ref>
===Buy Nothing Day=== November 23, 2001, WAAKE-UP! members supported the [[Buy Nothing Day]] protests in [[Boulder, Colorado]], organized by CU-Boulder professor Kayann Short, who focused it on how [[consumerism]] affects women.<ref name="BND-LIST">{{cite mailing list|url=http://www.ddh.nl/pipermail/bnd-list/2001/000050.html |title=Why Shop? Week in Colorado |date=2001-11-17 |accessdate=2007-09-19 |mailinglist=Bnd-list |last=Short |first=Kayann |archivedate=2007-10-20 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071020073527/http://www.ddh.nl/pipermail/bnd-list/2001/000050.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="ANTICONSUMERISM">{{cite news|author=Fred Baerkircher |title=U. Colorado instructor launches anti-consumerism campaign |date=2001-11-15 |publisher=University Wire |accessdate=2007-09-22 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-48239447.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516201751/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-48239447.html |archivedate=May 16, 2011 }}</ref>
===The People's Summit on Globalization=== WAAKE-UP! supported the [[People's Summit]] on Globalization, a conference discussing how [[globalization]] affects people around the world. The conference focused specifically on institutions such as the [[World Bank]], [[International Monetary Fund]], and the [[World Trade Organization]]. The conference was held March 8–11, 2001, and featured speakers such as [[Paul Hawken]], Chol Soon Rhie, Danny Kennedy, [[Kevin Danaher (activist)|Kevin Danaher]], Ignacio Ibarra, Njoki Njoroge Njehu, Raquel Sancho, [[Amy Goodman]], Julie Davids, Carlos Zorrilla, Michael Morrill, Orrin Williams, [[Ward Churchill]], Evelyn Hu-DeHart, Irungu Houghton, Jason Wallach, and William Begay.<ref name="PEOPLESUMMIT">{{cite web|url=http://www.colorado.edu/StudentGroups/summit/ |title=The People's Summit on Globalization and Concurrent Events : "A conference to educate, empower, and united people striving for justice in the face of corporate globalization" |date=2001-03-08 |author=The Coalition for Economic Justice |archivedate=2010-01-03 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mUmhfpe5?url=http://www.colorado.edu/StudentGroups/summit/ |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===The Rocky Mountain Rebels=== '''The Rocky Mountain Rebels''' were a group of [[Radical cheerleading|Radical Cheerleaders]] in WAAKE-UP!. They were present at nearly every WAAKE-UP! demonstration cheering on the protesters.<ref name="BECKEREJ">{{cite web|url=http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~beckerej/Home.html|author=Emily Becker|title=Radical Cheerleaders|accessdate=2007-09-19|year=2000|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010725092749/http://ucsub.colorado.edu/~beckerej/Home.html|archivedate=2001-07-25}}</ref><ref name="RADICALRUSH">{{cite news|author=Lisa Parker |title=U. Colorado Radical Rush week kicks off with film |date=2000-09-13 |publisher=University Wire |accessdate=2007-09-22 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-31823277.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516200648/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-31823277.html |archivedate=May 16, 2011 }}</ref>
===Radical Rush=== As an alternative to [[Fraternities and sororities|fraternity and sorority]] rushes, WAAKE-UP! members held a "Radical Rush" at the beginning of each semester in an attempt to get incoming students acquainted with all of the radical student organizations on campus.<ref name="RADICALRUSH"/><ref name="RADICALRUSHSITE">{{cite web|url=http://www.colorado.edu/studentgroups/radicalrush/|title=Radical Rush|accessdate=2007-09-19|year=2001|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010911041255/http://www.colorado.edu/studentgroups/radicalrush/|archivedate=2001-09-11}}</ref><ref name="RADICALRUSH2001">{{cite news|author=Jessika Fruchter |title=Alternative rush kicks off at U. Colorado |date=2001-09-05 |publisher=University Wire |accessdate=2007-09-22 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-46686422.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516201327/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-46686422.html |archivedate=May 16, 2011 }}</ref> The Radical Rush tradition continued after WAAKE-UP! was defunct.<ref name="RADICALRUSH2002">{{cite news|author=Jenny Atchley |title='Radical Rush' week exposes U. Colorado students to activist groups |date=2002-09-03 |publisher=University Wire |accessdate=2007-09-22 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-55877917.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516200947/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-55877917.html |archivedate=May 16, 2011 }}</ref>
===This Is What Democracy Looks Like=== November 30, 2000, WAAKE-UP! co-sponsored showings of the film ''This Is What Democracy Looks Like'' along with End Sanctions Now!, the Rocky Mountain Independent Media Center, AMP, Art & Revolution, [[Free Speech TV]] and [[KGNU]].<ref name="LOOKSLIKE1">{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisdemocracy.org/n30.html|title=THIS IS WHAT DEMOCRACY LOOKS LIKE|accessdate=2007-09-19|date=November 2000|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051215090901/http://www.thisisdemocracy.org/n30.html|archivedate=2005-12-15}}</ref><ref name="LOOKSLIKE2">{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisdemocracy.org/7_n30list.html|title=THIS IS WHAT DEMOCRACY LOOKS LIKE|accessdate=2007-09-19|date=November 2000|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061230091833/http://www.thisisdemocracy.org/7_n30list.html|archivedate=2006-12-30}}</ref>
===Unity 2000=== WAAKE-UP! endorsed Unity 2000, a group of concerned citizens and activists who protested at the [[Republican National Convention]] in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] on July 30, 2000.<ref name="ABOLITION">{{cite mailing list|url=http://www.xmission.com/pub/lists/abolition-usa/archive/v01.n300 |title=Should political parties be able to endorse Unity 2000? |date=2000-05-10 |accessdate=2007-09-19 |mailinglist=abolition-usa-digest |last=Morrill |first=Michael |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mUmotpzR?url=http://www.xmission.com/pub/lists/abolition-usa/archive/v01.n300 |archivedate=2010-01-03 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="GENDERRADIO">{{cite episode|title=GenderTalk|series=2000 Programs|url=http://www.gendertalk.com/radio/programs/251/gt266.shtml|credits=Hosted by Nancy Nangeroni and Gordene O. MacKenzie. Featuring Daviko Marcel (transman and director of Boston's Transgender Education Network, and partner [name removed by request], on ground breaking research on health care needs for trans persons) and Michael Morrill (organizer of the upcoming "Unity 2000 March" in Philadelphia during the Republican National Convention)|station=WMBR|location=[[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]|airdate=2000-07-10|number=266|archivedate=2015-09-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150910035033/http://www.gendertalk.com/radio/programs/251/gt266.shtml}}</ref>
==Presence in the Denver Police spy files== The Colorado [[ACLU]] was able to obtain files collected by the FBI's [[Joint Terrorism Task Force]] while working with local law enforcement in [[Denver, Colorado]] as a result of the Denver Police Spy File litigation. The files show that emails were intercepted from WAAKE-UP!'s email list, specifically about a protest planned for the Aspen Institutes's Summit on Globalization and the Human Condition in July 2000. Tim DeLaria of the CU-Boulder police department intercepted the email and forwarded it to George Kennedy in the Denver Police Department's Intelligence Unit. Kennedy wrote back to Tim DeLaria saying he would forward the email to Tom Fisher of the FBI Joint Terrorism Task Force to contact someone in [[Aspen, Colorado]].<ref name="SPYFILESX">{{cite web|url=http://www.coloradoaclu.org/spyfiles/fbifiles.htm |author=ACLU of Colorado |title=ACLU of Colorado: Spy Files |accessdate=2007-09-19 |date=2006-02-24 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mUkeulc8?url=http://www.aclu-co.org/spyfiles/fbifiles.htm |archivedate=2010-01-03 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
In addition to the exchange about the Aspen Institutes's Summit on Globalization, it also includes an exchange between Tim DeLaria and the Denver Police Department about a march organized by WAAKE-UP! in support of the [[U'wa people|U'wa]].<ref name="DELARIA2000">{{cite mailing list|url=http://www.siliconashes.net/~talbert/emails.pdf |title=Fw: MARCH FOR THE U'wa (fwd) |date=2000-10-06 |accessdate=2010-01-02 |mailinglist=waake-up |last=Delaria |first=Tim |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mUn1tJ0M?url=http://www.siliconashes.net/~talbert/emails.pdf |archivedate=2010-01-03 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The WAAKE-UP! email list was one of 24 lists mentioned in a [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|FOIA]] request by the Colorado ACLU in relation to the Denver Police Spy files case.<ref name="SILVERSTEIN2004">{{cite journal|title=Re: Request under Freedom of Information Act and Privacy Act |date=2004-12-02 |last=Silverstein |first=Mark |url=https://www.aclu.org/FilesPDFs/foia_co.pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mUq2f9Sw?url=http://www.aclu.org/FilesPDFs/foia_co.pdf |archivedate=2010-01-03 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Criticism== Linda Gorman of the [[Independence Institute]] wrote two articles decrying WAAKE-UP!.<ref name="GORMAN2000A">{{cite web|title=Linda Gorman|publisher=Independence Institute |date=2000-05-18|url=http://www.i2i.org/main/author.php?author_id=80|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061003124227/http://www.i2i.org/main/article.php?article_id=288|archivedate=2006-10-03}}</ref> Gorman claimed that policies advocated by WAAKE-UP! would put the working poor making [[University of Colorado Boulder|University of Colorado]] apparel out of work. Gorman was also very critical of Sara Toombs' choice of fillings for the pie baked to [[Pieing|pie]] Chancellor Byyny; stating that at the time of year when the pie was baked [[blueberries]] were out of season and may have been imported by a corporation exploiting its workers south of the United States border. Gorman suggested Toombs should have made a [[rhubarb]] pie, as rhubarb was in season at the time.<ref name="GORMAN2000B">{{cite web|author=Linda Gorman |title=Against Everything, For What? |publisher=Independence Institute |date=2000-05-03 |accessdate=2007-09-21 |url=http://www.i2i.org/main/article.php?article_id=284 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928021517/http://www.i2i.org/main/article.php?article_id=284 |archivedate=2007-09-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="GORMAN2000C">{{cite web|author=Linda Gorman |title=WAAKE-UP! and Feel Better—Throw the Poor Our of Work |publisher=Independence Institute |date=2000-05-18 |accessdate=2007-09-21 |url=http://www.i2i.org/main/article.php?article_id=288 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061003124227/http://www.i2i.org/main/article.php?article_id=288 |archivedate=2006-10-03 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>

{{Redirect|WRDA|the radio station WRDA|WRDA (FM)}} '''Water Resources Development Act''' (WRDA), is a reference to public laws enacted by Congress to deal with various aspects of water resources: environmental, structural, navigational, flood protection, hydrology, etc.
Typically, the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]] administers the bulk of the Act's requirements.
There are several WRDAs:
* [[Water Resources Development Act of 1974]], WRDA 1974, {{USPL|93|251}} * [[Water Resources Development Act of 1976]], WRDA 1976, {{USPL|94|587}} * [[Water Resources Development Act of 1986]], WRDA 1986, {{USPL|99|662}} ([http://www.taxpayer.net/corpswatch/PDF/WRDA86.pdf WRDA86.pdf], via TaxPayer.net) * [[Water Resources Development Act of 1988]], WRDA 1988, {{USPL|100|676}} * [[Water Resources Development Act of 1990]], WRDA 1990, {{USPL|101|640}} * [[Water Resources Development Act of 1992]], WRDA 1992, {{USPL|102|580}} * [[Water Resources Development Act of 1996]], WRDA 1996, {{USPL|104|303}} * [[Water Resources Development Act of 1999]], WRDA 1999, {{USPL|106|53}} * [[Water Resources Development Act of 2000]], WRDA 2000, {{USPL|106|541}} * [[Water Resources Development Act of 2007]], WRDA 2007, {{USPL|110|114}} * [[Water Resources Development Act of 2014]], WRDA 2014, {{USPL|113|121}} * [[Water Resources Development Act of 2016]], WRDA 2016, included as part of the [[Water Infrastructure Improvements for the Nation Act]] (WIIN Act), {{USPL|114|322}}
